===Johnny Bright===
===Johnny Bright===
â
[[File:Johnny Bright Incident.jpg|left|thumb|Johnny Bright Incident - Oct. 21, 1951 ''Des Moines Register'' newspaper cover showing Robinson and Ultang photo sequence]]
+
{{Main|Johnny Bright}}
â
+
In 1951, 'Johnny Bright was named a First Team [[College Football All-America Team|College Football All-American]], and was awarded the [[Nils V. "Swede" Nelson Award|Nils V. "Swede" Nelson Sportsmanship Award]]. He was invited to the [[Heisman Trophy]] festivities and finished fifth in the voting.
â
In 1951, [[Johnny Bright]] was named a First Team [[College Football All-America Team|College Football All-American]], and was awarded the [[Nils V. "Swede" Nelson Award|Nils V. "Swede" Nelson Sportsmanship Award]]. He was invited to the [[Heisman Trophy]] festivities and finished fifth in the voting.
 
In 1969, Bright was named Drake University's greatest football player of all time. Bright is the only Drake football player to have his jersey number (#43) retired by the school, and in June, 2006, received honorable mention from ''[[ESPN]].com'' senior writer Ivan Maisel as one of the best college football players to ever wear #43.<ref name="Johnny Bright's Football Jersey Number Recognized">{{cite web |url=http://www.drakebulldogs.org/football/newsstory.php?nid=1151679923 |accessdate=2006-07-08 |title=Johnny Bright's Football Jersey Number Recognized |publisher=DrakeBulldogs.org |date=2006-06-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060711061727/http://www.drakebulldogs.org/football/newsstory.php?nid=1151679923 |archivedate = 2006-07-11}}</ref> In February 2006, the football field at [[Drake Stadium]], in [[Des Moines, Iowa]], was named in his honor.<ref name="KCCI-TV8 Des Moines, Iowa - Drake Names Football Field After Johnny Bright: OSU Apologizes For Player's Actions">{{cite web |url=http://www.kcci.com/sports/7374962/detail.html?rss=des&psp=sports |accessdate=2006-08-12 | title=KCCI-TV8 Des Moines, Iowa - Drake Names Football Field After Johnny Bright: OSU Apologizes For Player's Actions |publisher=KCCI.com |date=2006-02-23}}</ref> In November 2006, Bright was voted one of the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]]'s [[TSN Top 50 CFL Players|Top 50 players]] (#19) of the league's modern era by Canadian sports network [[The Sports Network|TSN]].<ref name="TSN Top 50 CFL Players">{{cite web |url=http://www.tsn.ca/cfl/feature/?fid=10866 |accessdate=2007-04-28 |title=TSN Top 50 CFL Players |publisher=TSN.ca |date=2006-11-28}}</ref>
In 1969, Bright was named Drake University's greatest football player of all time. Bright is the only Drake football player to have his jersey number (#43) retired by the school, and in June, 2006, received honorable mention from ''[[ESPN]].com'' senior writer Ivan Maisel as one of the best college football players to ever wear #43.<ref name="Johnny Bright's Football Jersey Number Recognized">{{cite web |url=http://www.drakebulldogs.org/football/newsstory.php?nid=1151679923 |accessdate=2006-07-08 |title=Johnny Bright's Football Jersey Number Recognized |publisher=DrakeBulldogs.org |date=2006-06-30 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20060711061727/http://www.drakebulldogs.org/football/newsstory.php?nid=1151679923 |archivedate = 2006-07-11}}</ref> In February 2006, the football field at [[Drake Stadium]], in [[Des Moines, Iowa]], was named in his honor.<ref name="KCCI-TV8 Des Moines, Iowa - Drake Names Football Field After Johnny Bright: OSU Apologizes For Player's Actions">{{cite web |url=http://www.kcci.com/sports/7374962/detail.html?rss=des&psp=sports |accessdate=2006-08-12 | title=KCCI-TV8 Des Moines, Iowa - Drake Names Football Field After Johnny Bright: OSU Apologizes For Player's Actions |publisher=KCCI.com |date=2006-02-23}}</ref> In November 2006, Bright was voted one of the [[Canadian Football League|CFL]]'s [[TSN Top 50 CFL Players|Top 50 players]] (#19) of the league's modern era by Canadian sports network [[The Sports Network|TSN]].<ref name="TSN Top 50 CFL Players">{{cite web |url=http://www.tsn.ca/cfl/feature/?fid=10866 |accessdate=2007-04-28 |title=TSN Top 50 CFL Players |publisher=TSN.ca |date=2006-11-28}}</ref>
====Johnny Bright incident====
====Johnny Bright incident====
â
The [[Johnny Bright Incident]] was a violent [[Violence in sports|on-field assault]] against [[African-American]] player [[Johnny Bright]] by [[White American]] player Wilbanks Smith during an American [[college football]] game held on October 20, 1951 in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]]. The game was significant in itself as it marked the first time that an African American athlete with a national profile and of critical importance to the success of his [[Drake University]] team had played against Oklahoma A&M (now [[Oklahoma State University - Stillwater|Oklahoma State University]]) on their [[Home (sports)|home field]]. Bright's injury also highlighted the racial tensions of the times and assumed notoriety when it was captured in what was later to become both a widely disseminated and eventually [[Pulitzer Prize]] winning photo sequence. The event later came to be known as the "Johnny Bright Incident".
+
{{Main|Johnny Bright Incident}}
  +
The Johnny Bright Incident was a violent [[Violence in sports|on-field assault]] against [[African-American]] player [[Johnny Bright]] by [[White American]] player Wilbanks Smith during an American [[college football]] game held on October 20, 1951 in [[Stillwater, Oklahoma]]. The game was significant in itself as it marked the first time that an African American athlete with a national profile and of critical importance to the success of his [[Drake University]] team had played against Oklahoma A&M (now [[Oklahoma State University - Stillwater|Oklahoma State University]]) on their [[Home (sports)|home field]]. Bright's injury also highlighted the racial tensions of the times and assumed notoriety when it was captured in what was later to become both a widely disseminated and eventually [[Pulitzer Prize]] winning photo sequence. The event later came to be known as the "Johnny Bright Incident".
===Near perfect 1981 season===
===Near perfect 1981 season===
